lines.text: Enter LEONATO and ANTONIO

lines.speaker: antonio
lines.text: If you go on thus, you will kill yourself: And 'tis not wisdom thus to second grief Against yourself.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: I pray thee, cease thy counsel, Which falls into mine ears as profitless As water in a sieve: give not me counsel; Nor let no comforter delight mine ear But such a one whose wrongs do suit with mine. Bring me a father that so loved his child, Whose joy of her is overwhelm'd like mine, And bid him speak of patience; Measure his woe the length and breadth of mine And let it answer every strain for strain, As thus for thus and such a grief for such, In every lineament, branch, shape, and form: If such a one will smile and stroke his beard, Bid sorrow wag, cry 'hem!' when he should groan, Patch grief with proverbs, make misfortune drunk With candle-wasters; bring him yet to me, And I of him will gather patience. But there is no such man: for, brother, men Can counsel and speak comfort to that grief Which they themselves not feel; but, tasting it, Their counsel turns to passion, which before Would give preceptial medicine to rage, Fetter strong madness in a silken thread, Charm ache with air and agony with words: No, no; 'tis all men's office to speak patience To those that wring under the load of sorrow, But no man's virtue nor sufficiency To be so moral when he shall endure The like himself. Therefore give me no counsel: My griefs cry louder than advertisement.

lines.speaker: antonio
lines.text: Therein do men from children nothing differ.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: I pray thee, peace. I will be flesh and blood; For there was never yet philosopher That could endure the toothache patiently, However they have writ the style of gods And made a push at chance and sufferance.

lines.speaker: antonio
lines.text: Yet bend not all the harm upon yourself; Make those that do offend you suffer too.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: There thou speak'st reason: nay, I will do so. My soul doth tell me Hero is belied; And that shall Claudio know; so shall the prince And all of them that thus dishonour her.

lines.speaker: antonio
lines.text: Here comes the prince and Claudio hastily.
Enter DON PEDRO and CLAUDIO

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Good den, good den.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Good day to both of you.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Hear you. my lords,--

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: We have some haste, Leonato.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Some haste, my lord! well, fare you well, my lord: Are you so hasty now? well, all is one.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Nay, do not quarrel with us, good old man.

lines.speaker: antonio
lines.text: If he could right himself with quarreling, Some of us would lie low.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Who wrongs him?

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Marry, thou dost wrong me; thou dissembler, thou:-- Nay, never lay thy hand upon thy sword; I fear thee not.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Marry, beshrew my hand, If it should give your age such cause of fear: In faith, my hand meant nothing to my sword.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Tush, tush, man; never fleer and jest at me: I speak not like a dotard nor a fool, As under privilege of age to brag What I have done being young, or what would do Were I not old. Know, Claudio, to thy head, Thou hast so wrong'd mine innocent child and me That I am forced to lay my reverence by And, with grey hairs and bruise of many days, Do challenge thee to trial of a man. I say thou hast belied mine innocent child; Thy slander hath gone through and through her heart, And she lies buried with her ancestors; O, in a tomb where never scandal slept, Save this of hers, framed by thy villany!

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: My villany?

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Thine, Claudio; thine, I say.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: You say not right, old man.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: My lord, my lord, I'll prove it on his body, if he dare, Despite his nice fence and his active practise, His May of youth and bloom of lustihood.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Away! I will not have to do with you.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Canst thou so daff me? Thou hast kill'd my child: If thou kill'st me, boy, thou shalt kill a man.

lines.speaker: antonio
lines.text: He shall kill two of us, and men indeed: But that's no matter; let him kill one first; Win me and wear me; let him answer me. Come, follow me, boy; come, sir boy, come, follow me: Sir boy, I'll whip you from your foining fence; Nay, as I am a gentleman, I will.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Brother,--

lines.speaker: antonio
lines.text: Content yourself. God knows I loved my niece; And she is dead, slander'd to death by villains, That dare as well answer a man indeed As I dare take a serpent by the tongue: Boys, apes, braggarts, Jacks, milksops!

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Brother Antony,--

lines.speaker: antonio
lines.text: Hold you content. What, man! I know them, yea, And what they weigh, even to the utmost scruple,-- Scrambling, out-facing, fashion-monging boys, That lie and cog and flout, deprave and slander, Go anticly, show outward hideousness, And speak off half a dozen dangerous words, How they might hurt their enemies, if they durst; And this is all.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: But, brother Antony,--

lines.speaker: antonio
lines.text: Come, 'tis no matter: Do not you meddle; let me deal in this.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Gentlemen both, we will not wake your patience. My heart is sorry for your daughter's death: But, on my honour, she was charged with nothing But what was true and very full of proof.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: My lord, my lord,--

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: I will not hear you.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: No? Come, brother; away! I will be heard.

lines.speaker: antonio
lines.text: And shall, or some of us will smart for it.
Exeunt LEONATO and ANTONIO

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: See, see; here comes the man we went to seek.
Enter BENEDICK

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Now, signior, what news?

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Good day, my lord.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Welcome, signior: you are almost come to part almost a fray.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: We had like to have had our two noses snapped off with two old men without teeth.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Leonato and his brother. What thinkest thou? Had we fought, I doubt we should have been too young for them.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: In a false quarrel there is no true valour. I came to seek you both.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: We have been up and down to seek thee; for we are high-proof melancholy and would fain have it beaten away. Wilt thou use thy wit?

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: It is in my scabbard: shall I draw it?

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Dost thou wear thy wit by thy side?

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Never any did so, though very many have been beside their wit. I will bid thee draw, as we do the minstrels; draw, to pleasure us.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: As I am an honest man, he looks pale. Art thou sick, or angry?

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: What, courage, man! What though care killed a cat, thou hast mettle enough in thee to kill care.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Sir, I shall meet your wit in the career, and you charge it against me. I pray you choose another subject.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Nay, then, give him another staff: this last was broke cross.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: By this light, he changes more and more: I think he be angry indeed.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: If he be, he knows how to turn his girdle.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Shall I speak a word in your ear?

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: God bless me from a challenge!

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: [Aside to CLAUDIO]  You are a villain; I jest not: I will make it good how you dare, with what you dare, and when you dare. Do me right, or I will protest your cowardice. You have killed a sweet lady, and her death shall fall heavy on you. Let me hear from you.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Well, I will meet you, so I may have good cheer.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: What, a feast, a feast?

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: I' faith, I thank him; he hath bid me to a calf's head and a capon; the which if I do not carve most curiously, say my knife's naught. Shall I not find a woodcock too?

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Sir, your wit ambles well; it goes easily.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: I'll tell thee how Beatrice praised thy wit the other day. I said, thou hadst a fine wit: 'True,' said she, 'a fine little one.' 'No,' said I, 'a great wit:' 'Right,' says she, 'a great gross one.' 'Nay,' said I, 'a good wit:' 'Just,' said she, 'it hurts nobody.' 'Nay,' said I, 'the gentleman is wise:' 'Certain,' said she, 'a wise gentleman.' 'Nay,' said I, 'he hath the tongues:' 'That I believe,' said she, 'for he swore a thing to me on Monday night, which he forswore on Tuesday morning; there's a double tongue; there's two tongues.' Thus did she, an hour together, transshape thy particular virtues: yet at last she concluded with a sigh, thou wast the properest man in Italy.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: For the which she wept heartily and said she cared not.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Yea, that she did: but yet, for all that, an if she did not hate him deadly, she would love him dearly: the old man's daughter told us all.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: All, all; and, moreover, God saw him when he was hid in the garden.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: But when shall we set the savage bull's horns on the sensible Benedick's head?

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Yea, and text underneath, 'Here dwells Benedick the married man'?

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Fare you well, boy: you know my mind. I will leave you now to your gossip-like humour: you break jests as braggarts do their blades, which God be thanked, hurt not. My lord, for your many courtesies I thank you: I must discontinue your company: your brother the bastard is fled from Messina: you have among you killed a sweet and innocent lady. For my Lord Lackbeard there, he and I shall meet: and, till then, peace be with him.
Exit

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: He is in earnest.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: In most profound earnest; and, I'll warrant you, for the love of Beatrice.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: And hath challenged thee.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Most sincerely.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: What a pretty thing man is when he goes in his doublet and hose and leaves off his wit!

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: He is then a giant to an ape; but then is an ape a doctor to such a man.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: But, soft you, let me be: pluck up, my heart, and be sad. Did he not say, my brother was fled?
Enter DOGBERRY, VERGES, and the Watch, with CONRADE and BORACHIO

lines.speaker: dogberry
lines.text: Come you, sir: if justice cannot tame you, she shall ne'er weigh more reasons in her balance: nay, an you be a cursing hypocrite once, you must be looked to.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: How now? two of my brother's men bound! Borachio one!

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Hearken after their offence, my lord.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Officers, what offence have these men done?

lines.speaker: dogberry
lines.text: Marry, sir, they have committed false report; moreover, they have spoken untruths; secondarily, they are slanders; sixth and lastly, they have belied a lady; thirdly, they have verified unjust things; and, to conclude, they are lying knaves.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: First, I ask thee what they have done; thirdly, I ask thee what's their offence; sixth and lastly, why they are committed; and, to conclude, what you lay to their charge.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Rightly reasoned, and in his own division: and, by my troth, there's one meaning well suited.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Who have you offended, masters, that you are thus bound to your answer? this learned constable is too cunning to be understood: what's your offence?

lines.speaker: borachio
lines.text: Sweet prince, let me go no farther to mine answer: do you hear me, and let this count kill me. I have deceived even your very eyes: what your wisdoms could not discover, these shallow fools have brought to light: who in the night overheard me confessing to this man how Don John your brother incensed me to slander the Lady Hero, how you were brought into the orchard and saw me court Margaret in Hero's garments, how you disgraced her, when you should marry her: my villany they have upon record; which I had rather seal with my death than repeat over to my shame. The lady is dead upon mine and my master's false accusation; and, briefly, I desire nothing but the reward of a villain.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Runs not this speech like iron through your blood?

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: I have drunk poison whiles he utter'd it.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: But did my brother set thee on to this?

lines.speaker: borachio
lines.text: Yea, and paid me richly for the practise of it.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: He is composed and framed of treachery: And fled he is upon this villany.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Sweet Hero! now thy image doth appear In the rare semblance that I loved it first.

lines.speaker: dogberry
lines.text: Come, bring away the plaintiffs: by this time our sexton hath reformed Signior Leonato of the matter: and, masters, do not forget to specify, when time and place shall serve, that I am an ass.

lines.speaker: verges
lines.text: Here, here comes master Signior Leonato, and the Sexton too.
Re-enter LEONATO and ANTONIO, with the Sexton

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Which is the villain? let me see his eyes, That, when I note another man like him, I may avoid him: which of these is he?

lines.speaker: borachio
lines.text: If you would know your wronger, look on me.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Art thou the slave that with thy breath hast kill'd Mine innocent child?

lines.speaker: borachio
lines.text: Yea, even I alone.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: No, not so, villain; thou beliest thyself: Here stand a pair of honourable men; A third is fled, that had a hand in it. I thank you, princes, for my daughter's death: Record it with your high and worthy deeds: 'Twas bravely done, if you bethink you of it.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: I know not how to pray your patience; Yet I must speak. Choose your revenge yourself; Impose me to what penance your invention Can lay upon my sin: yet sinn'd I not But in mistaking.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: By my soul, nor I: And yet, to satisfy this good old man, I would bend under any heavy weight That he'll enjoin me to.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: I cannot bid you bid my daughter live; That were impossible: but, I pray you both, Possess the people in Messina here How innocent she died; and if your love Can labour ought in sad invention, Hang her an epitaph upon her tomb And sing it to her bones, sing it to-night: To-morrow morning come you to my house, And since you could not be my son-in-law, Be yet my nephew: my brother hath a daughter, Almost the copy of my child that's dead, And she alone is heir to both of us: Give her the right you should have given her cousin, And so dies my revenge.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: O noble sir, Your over-kindness doth wring tears from me! I do embrace your offer; and dispose For henceforth of poor Claudio.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: To-morrow then I will expect your coming; To-night I take my leave. This naughty man Shall face to face be brought to Margaret, Who I believe was pack'd in all this wrong, Hired to it by your brother.

lines.speaker: borachio
lines.text: No, by my soul, she was not, Nor knew not what she did when she spoke to me, But always hath been just and virtuous In any thing that I do know by her.

lines.speaker: dogberry
lines.text: Moreover, sir, which indeed is not under white and black, this plaintiff here, the offender, did call me ass: I beseech you, let it be remembered in his punishment. And also, the watch heard them talk of one Deformed: they say be wears a key in his ear and a lock hanging by it, and borrows money in God's name, the which he hath used so long and never paid that now men grow hard-hearted and will lend nothing for God's sake: pray you, examine him upon that point.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: I thank thee for thy care and honest pains.

lines.speaker: dogberry
lines.text: Your worship speaks like a most thankful and reverend youth; and I praise God for you.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: There's for thy pains.

lines.speaker: dogberry
lines.text: God save the foundation!

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Go, I discharge thee of thy prisoner, and I thank thee.

lines.speaker: dogberry
lines.text: I leave an arrant knave with your worship; which I beseech your worship to correct yourself, for the example of others. God keep your worship! I wish your worship well; God restore you to health! I humbly give you leave to depart; and if a merry meeting may be wished, God prohibit it! Come, neighbour.
Exeunt DOGBERRY and VERGES

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Until to-morrow morning, lords, farewell.

lines.speaker: antonio
lines.text: Farewell, my lords: we look for you to-morrow.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: We will not fail.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: To-night I'll mourn with Hero.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: [To the Watch]  Bring you these fellows on. We'll talk with Margaret, How her acquaintance grew with this lewd fellow.
Exeunt, severally
